awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Magmatic Processes of the McMurdo Dry Valleys
awd_abstract_narration:
This work will explore first order principles governing magmatic processes for most planetary magmatic systems, particularly the spatial interdependence of physical and chemical processes. These basic principles are essential to planetary differentiation, the bimodality of sea floor basalt and continental granitics, modal layering in basaltic plutons, and the diversity of igneous rocks. This research will be conducted using samples from the Ferrar Magmatic System of the McMurdo Dry Valleys. The PIs seek to: 1) Complete a 1:100,000 geologic map of the entire Dry Valleys that traces in detail the extent and interactions of all the sills to help understand magmatic processes recorded by the entire system; 2) Complete analyses to establish the extent of a newly discovered Opx-Tongue in the Peneplain sill and fingerprint the two upper sills; 3) Simulate the dynamics of sorting and self-organization of granular materials dynamically similar to the massive slurries of the Dais Layered Intrusion. This work is highly integrated in its use of field, theoretical, and experimental methods to reveal and contribute to solving long-standing problems in magma transport, solidification, and differentiation. 

Broader impacts: 
Previous work by this PI has had broad scientific impacts on Antarctic Earth Sciences. The results of his work have been used to design museum exhibits, to understand ore deposition, and to understand the mitigation of magmatic hazards. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in the course of this research.

por.por_cntn:
The principal aim of this work was to reveal and explore some key first order fundamental principles governing magmatic processes, especially the spatial interdependence of physical and chemical processes.  These basic principles are essential to planetary differentiation, the bimodality of sea floor basalt and continental granitics, modal layering in basaltic plutons, and the very diversity of igneous rocks.   The central concept is that of a ‘carrier magma’ that entrains, transports and deposits extant crystals, indigenous and not, in proportion to the local transport flux. In essence, it is shown that physical and mechanical processes buttressed by chemical diffusive processes govern magmatic systems. Physical situations are established that chemistry must attend to. The laboratory for this research was the Ferrar Magmatic System of the McMurdo Dry Valleys, which is truly singular in its exemplification of a physically and chemically highly integrated magmatic system that reveals this principle. The field recognition, theoretical understanding, and experimental simulation of the physics and chemistry of the workings of this magmatic system are each at the very core of this work. Among a host of other work, we accomplished: 1) Completed a 1:100,000 geologic map of the entire Dry Valleys that traces in detail the extent and interactions of all the sills. This is at the core of understanding the magmatic processes recorded by the entire system; 2) Completed an analysis of sampling profiles to establish the extent of a newly discovered Opx-Tongue in the Peneplain sill and fingerprint the two upper sills; 3) Simulated the dynamics of sorting and self-organization of granular materials dynamically similar to the massive slurries of the Dais Layered Intrusion.

Intellectual Merit: This work made fundamental contributions to understanding the initiation, establishment, and functioning of a highly integrated magmatic delivery system within Earth’s crust. This work is itself also highly integrated in its use of field, theoretical, and experimental methods to reveal and contribute to solving long-standing problems in magma transport, solidification, and differentiation. This effort has clear implications for the behavior of the most general planetary magmatic systems. We have a long research record in this area and of this style and have made original contributions to understanding the physics and chemistry of fluids undergoing convection and flow during solidification. We try to offer provocative, new ideas and concepts on magmatic processes that can be understood and enriched by other branches of the Natural sciences and mechanical and chemical engineering.

Broader Impacts: The work by this PI has established a ‘School of Thought’ on planetary magmatic processes. Thirty two Ph.Ds. have come from this effort, 40% women, Hispanic, and African American. These are notable professionals in Academics, National labs., and Federal Agencies. The insights of this general effort are used to design museum exhibits, to understand ore deposition, and to understand the mitigation of magmatic hazards. This work is interwoven with undergraduate research here and elsewhere throughout the world, with elementary and high schools, through numerous special lectures (34 were given on this work).
